awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Cellular and Molecular Analysis of a Specific Retinal Lineage that Generates Cone Photoreceptors and Horizontal Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
An embryo develops from a single cell and this cell generates new cells with increasingly specific functions. For each tissue, there are progenitor cells that then generate more new cells that make up that tissue. Cells that allow us to see color, cone photoreceptors, are formed from progenitor cells in the developing eye. This project will focus on how the progenitor cells form these photoreceptors. The information that directs this process is found in DNA.  Experiments will use specific DNA sequences that are involved in the formation of cone photoreceptors to track the progenitor cells in real time as they change into new cells that become cone photoreceptors. This research is expected to lead to new insights into how unique cells are formed during eye development. In addition, this project will engage early stage undergraduates to participate in both this research project and to be leaders of an outreach activity to the New York Public School system. Middle school students will be introduced to what it is to be a scientist, which will open the door to the possibility that they can also become one. This CAREER award will allow the Principal Investigator to develop a sustainable integrated research and outreach program at a large minority serving institution in Harlem.

It has recently been recognized that there are retinal progenitor cell populations that are restricted in the cell types that they will generate. The goal of this study is to investigate one of these populations that preferentially generates cone photoreceptors and horizontal cells. To accomplish this, multiple approaches that use cell-type specific transcriptional regulatory elements will be applied. At the cellular level, these elements will be used to determine the subtypes of cone and horizontal cells formed from these progenitor cells. In addition, live imaging will be used to analyze the daughter fates of single cone/horizontal cell progenitors to define the heterogeneity of the lineage. At the molecular level, the role of the Notch-Delta signaling pathway in this progenitor lineage will be examined. Finally, whole transcriptome and epigenome signatures of cells as they transition through the cone/horizontal cell progenitor lineage will be determined. At its conclusion, this project is expected to provide a novel molecular examination of a genetically defined retinal lineage.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Cone photoreceptors are specialized cells in the eye that detect light in bright conditions. These cells are found in a layer of central nervous system tissue lining the inside of the eye that contains many types of neurons. All of these cells are formed from a population of cells that divide to form more cells and a process of ordered gene expression controls what specific types of cells are formed. The identification of these gene pathways and how they are coordinated to make an eye with all of the right types of neurons in the right proportions is critical for our understanding of how information encoded in our genetic material (DNA) can direct the formation of a complex brain tissue.

            This project examined how cone photoreceptors are made in the embryo using sequences found in the DNA that instruct where and when genes are expressed. To do so, these DNA sequences were modified in the lab so that when they were introduced into living embryos, they would make populations of cells fluoresce (glow). A specific population of dividing cells (called progenitor cells) that forms cone photoreceptor and horizontal cell daughter cells was studied. This population of cells was isolated and studied to determine what specific DNA elements were likely active (thru epigenomic analysis) to promote the formation of these two cell types. Elements that were active in this dividing population of cells as well as horizontal cells (one of the daughter cells) were identified and the DNA sequences were analyzed. To determine what type of daughter cells were made we developed a DNA-based system called lineage tracing that could trace cells over time that activate specific elements. This system was used to identify that the daughter cells of cone/HC progenitors are specific subtypes of horizontal cells and also to determine in what cells specific DNA elements are activated. This deepens our understanding of how genes are activated in specific times and places to form cone photoreceptors and horizontal cells. In addition, a specific pathway called the Notch-Delta pathway was found to affect the formation of cone photoreceptors by controlling the production of cone/horizontal cell progenitors. Lastly, we examined the genetic and developmental changes in animals with different numbers of cone photoreceptors and horizontal cells. This included the little skate (Leucoraja erinacea) which has no cone photoreceptors and the rodent thirteen lined ground squirrel which has a cone dominant retina.

            This study also aimed to broaden the participation of trainees in scientific research and to engage them in outreach to a younger generation of developing scientists. Twenty-five undergraduate students from The City College of New York in Harlem actively participated in this research with nine of these students entering Doctoral programs to continue their research interests. In addition, three Doctoral students and two Masters students were trained in scientific research including research design, experimental rigor, scientific communication, and data analysis. Undergraduate students developed and led two-day outreach activities with over 1,300 local New York City public middle school students, including visits to the middle school alma maters of five of these students.

Taken together, this project integrated training of students at multiple levels of education, basic scientific investigation, and outreach to the next generation of scientists within our local community of New York City.


Last Modified: 08/28/2024
Modified by: Mark M Emerson
